title: Trump says Starmer and Macron 'haven't done anything' to end Ukraine war 8 minutes ago Max Matza BBC News Watch: Zelensky will sign rare mineral deal soon, says US National Security Advisor Mike Waltz
body:
Zelensky has held phone calls with various global leaders in recent days, who have expressed their commitment to ensuring Ukraine is involved in peace talks.

Earlier this week, Starmer said he is "ready and willing" to put UK troops on the ground in Ukraine to help guarantee its security as part of a peace deal.

While European leaders have ruled out negotiating with Russia, they have met regularly to discuss the war in Ukraine - including at an emergency summit in Paris on Monday.

Since Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, the US, UK and EU, along with countries including Australia, Canada and Japan, have imposed more than 20,000 sanctions on Russia.

Many European nations have also signed agreements to support and provide aid to Ukraine. In January, Starmer signed a "landmark" 100-year pact, telling Zelensky: "We are with you not just today, for this year or the next - but for 100 years - long after this terrible war is over and Ukraine is free and thriving once again."

Trump, in his Fox interview on Friday, said Russia and Ukraine would not want to begin peace talks without his own personal involvement.

He also continued to criticise Zelensky, saying: "I've been watching this man for years now as his cities get demolished, as his people get killed, as his soldiers get decimated.

"I've been watching him negotiate with no cards. He has no cards, and you get sick of it," he continued. "You just get sick of it, and I've had it."

Despite his criticism of Macron and Starmer, Trump also praised the European leaders. He said he considers Macron to be a "friend", and called Starmer "a very nice guy".

Macron is expected to visit Washington DC on Monday, while Starmer is expected to arrive on Friday.

And after criticising Zelensky over the past week - using talking points that analysts say sound more like they originate in Moscow than Washington DC - Trump offered that "of course" he would take a phone call from Ukraine's president.

He insisted several times that Zelensky is to blame to failing to prevent war, saying that Russia could have been "talked out" of invading Ukraine.

Asked about Ukraine's absence at peace talks in Saudi Arabia this week, Trump said that Russia "found it impossible to make a deal with Zelensky".

He said he believes that Russia sincerely wants a deal to end the war, but that Russian President Vladimir Putin "doesn't have to make a deal".

US Vice-President JD Vance later hit back at critics who said that Trump's stance on Russia amounts to "appeasement".

wikidata_info.description: Prime Minister of the United Kingdom since 2024

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article quotes and references Keir Starmer, but does not explicitly state his title as UK Prime Minister; the description is inferred from common knowledge.

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article repeatedly mentions "Starmer" in contexts that align with Keir Starmer’s profile: a UK political leader, reference to UK troops, and a 100‑year pact with Ukraine. The article’s timeframe (mentions of recent weeks and a 2024 context) matches the Wikidata entry that lists Keir Starmer as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom since 2024. No other individual named Starmer is described, and the political role and national affiliation (UK) are consistent with the Wikidata entity. Therefore, the entity is present and correctly identified.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Keir Starmer is directly quoted in the article: "ready and willing" to deploy UK troops, and "We are with you not just today, for this year or the next – but for 100 years…" These are clear statements attributed to him. The article also reports that he signed a 100‑year pact, further indicating his active role.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the UK Prime Minister to discuss troop deployment and long‑term support for Ukraine, especially in the context of peace talks. The statements align with the responsibilities and public positions of a head of government.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions were found between the article’s depiction of Starmer and the Wikidata profile. The political role, national affiliation, and recent actions all match.

speaker_type.explanation: The article quotes and references Keir Starmer, but does not explicitly state his title as UK Prime Minister; the description is inferred from common knowledge.

classification_outcome.explanation: The article quotes and references Keir Starmer, but does not explicitly state his title as UK Prime Minister; the description is inferred from common knowledge.

political_party.name: Reform Party of the United States of America

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article quotes Donald Trump and refers to him as a former US President, matching both the name and the description.

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly references "Trump, in his Fox interview on Friday" and includes multiple direct quotations attributed to him. The name "Trump" is used in a context that clearly refers to Donald Trump, the former U.S. President, matching the target entity name and description.
reasoning.statement_detection: Donald Trump is quoted directly in several passages: "Trump, in his Fox interview on Friday, said Russia and Ukraine would not want to begin peace talks without his own personal involvement," and later statements about Zelensky and Russia. These are clear instances of the entity making statements.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Among the provided candidates, Q22686 is the only one that matches the description "Former US President" and the name "Donald Trump." The other candidates (Q27947481, Q3713655, Q23000825) are unrelated professions or family members. Therefore Q22686 is the best match.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q22686, as a former U.S. President, possesses the public authority and platform to make statements about international affairs. The article’s context (Fox interview) aligns with a typical setting for a former president’s commentary.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for a former U.S. President to comment on Ukraine‑Russia relations and to be quoted in a Fox interview. The statements are consistent with the public persona and political stance commonly associated with Donald Trump.
reasoning.final_justification: The entity "Donald Trump" is present in the article, is making statements, and the candidate Q22686 perfectly matches the target description and the context of the article. No other candidate fits the description or the quoted content.

speaker_type.explanation: The article quotes Donald Trump and refers to him as a former US President, matching both the name and the description.

classification_outcome.explanation: The article quotes Donald Trump and refers to him as a former US President, matching both the name and the description.
